pros: Positive work environment, family oriented environment
cons: Long  hours that make it hard to balance work and life at times.

job_title: Student Success Coordinator in Sparks, NV
pros: They have high expectations of professionalism combined with customer service skills. You will feel appreciated as an employee as long as you complete your task in a timely manner.
cons: Long hours of work and sometimes 8 hours a day is not enough to get everything done. However, they have a very generous PTO. I wish they improve their benefits such as healthcare and retirement benefits.

pros: The instructors and students are amazing.
cons: Nepotism-constructed hierarchy. Lots of favoritism shown to people in only slightly higher positions. If you're not one of these people - or you're lower on the job rung - you probably won't have a very good experience.

review_title: Could be so much more than it is.
job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in Sparks, NV
pros: Work was varied and kept things interesting. The part time hours were perfect for the type of work done.
Fun place to work, good training
cons: Little flexibility, low pay, no benefits

review_title: Instructors are considered the low man on the totem pole.
pros: Seeing students succeed is the only saving grace of this company. The four day work week helps. The work is easy if you have no desire for professional growth or challenges.
cons:
Instructors spend far too much time with administrative and disciplinary tasks. Isn't that what the administration is for? Seems like they share the same root word. 
Condescending and passive-aggressive emails about trivial things like coffee makers and copiers almost daily. 
Pay and benefits aren't competitive for those possessing an undergraduate degree with substantial experience. 
Sharing a 4 foot, half-cubicle with other people while people with ridiculous, made-up titles have entire offices. 
You lose a day of pay if there's a snow day, yet no compensation or means of "calling it even" when you work more than 40 hours a week. 
Can only take vacation on 5 non-consecutive designated weeks per year. 
I operate at about 10% of my capacity because hard work does not pay off. 
Too many more to list without depressing myself.

pros: I mostly feel like it's a family here.  I work with people I enjoy being around.  Running into our graduates in their new professions is a real motivation when I am out in our community.  Working with employers to make the curriculum fit their needs.
cons: Seeing a student fail hurts.  They have real lives that can drag them down sometimes and we have to remember that.  I have to say though that I have seen almost every employee here at some point in their tenure do everything within their power to help a student who needed it.  Wow...I just made the con a pro.

review_title: The  5-Star Reviews are a Sales Tactic!
pros:
The ability to help people begin a new career.

Benefits are competitive and include Vision, Dental, Medical and 401(K) after 2 years of full-time employment.
cons:
The people who made the reviews from June 2013 are the Admission Reps, aka: Sales Reps. They want to have a good online rating and are giving a false representation of the majority of the departments. Admissions is run by an amazing woman and she values her employees. Unfortunately, that is not true throughout the college.

Pay for the majority of the staff is below average, but it is a job.

Parking is a commodity in the morning if you get there after 7:45 a.m. because the parking lot is full and you end up parking either on the street or illegally in the dirt lot across the street.

review_title: Outstanding company that is concerned about the future and always looking for ways to improve.
pros: I enjoy working at the college because of the employees. Everyone that works here is an amazing person in their own way. I'm proud to be surrounded by such hard working people. I love that the company seems to be growing. The addition of new programs is creating some excitement and gives a feeling that I work for a company that has strength in a tough economic time.
cons: The company as a whole usually works good together. However, we work towards fixing problems between departments only to have problems between two other departments. There always seems to be a few individuals who are pulling the same rope in two different directions. I know that this is something that is always going to be an issue at any company you work at.

review_title: An overall warm and welcoming place for students AND employees.
pros:
The staff are some of the nicest and most helpful people I've ever had the pleasure of working with.
The level of team work and interdepartmental communication is on a whole other level I've never experienced before. 
There's a fluid transition between departments that's so seamless there isn't room left for confusion. 
Which benefits the employees work performance as well as the students first time experience and following experiences.
cons: Little to no space in the break room fridge for your lunch.

review_title: A good learning experience, but not in a positive way.
pros: Like the title says. The job was good experience and having it on my resume has helped a lot, but that is about it. See "cons" for more.
cons: Playing favorites and unfair treatment were big problems. If you were not certain roles, you were not treated very well. My treatment at the school gave me a warped view of how to properly react to things at work.

review_title: Decent place to work, depending on environment
pros: The hours are fairly flexible and the work is fairly easy. It's also fulfilling if teaching is your thing.
cons: Environment is fairly political. Curriculum is canned and there's not much room for creative curriculum design. You can get shafted pretty badly on scheduling sometimes. Pay is mediocre at best. Turnover is insane, and it can be somewhat stressful. Not much room for career growth, besides going into administration.

review_title: Great place if you're in the right department - beware of nepotism
pros: Fun environment, co workers are usually there with the motive to  help the students,  admissions is by far the best run and most rewarded of all departments .
cons: Rampant nepotism is worrisome and random firing makes everyone wonder "who's next?" And they have let go of some really amazing people. Pay is low to average.

pros:
Helping students learn and acquire skills that will help them in their careers. 
Curriculum is relevant and focused, with the ability to change it if the material needs updating.
Week of vacation every quarter. Generally 4x10hr shifts.
cons:
Split class shifts make for a crazy work schedule M-Th. 
Bureaucracy is through the roof. (Mostly due to being an accredited school)

pros: The relationships built with customers and co-workers is the best part of the job.  Helping solve prob elms in the community with direct feedback from employers who hire our graduates.  And last, but certainly not least, the "Bell Ringers".
cons: Split shifts that some of the faculty have to endure.

review_title: If you are looking to work here, you might want to re-think your choice
pros: In a shaky economy, it's a job
cons:
Cliquish infrastructure
Minimal opportunities for advancement
Your professional feedback is meaningless
Pay structure COMPLETELY out-of-line for a privatized "college" (trade school)

pros: Excellent staff, owners are honest and good people to work for.
